        Gets an array of double as parameter that will be stored internally
        Parameters:

    • Method Detail

      • at

        public double at(int i)
        O(n) method. Avoid it if it is possible!

      • size

        public int size()

      • getSampleRate

        public int getSampleRate()

      • setSampleRate

        public void setSampleRate(int s)

      • cloneSamples

        public void cloneSamples(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Double> target)
        Copies values to extern table. It doesn't returns a cloned table because if we want to copy the values to another signal we would have to do two loops (one for cloning the table, another time to add the values to the other signal).
        Parameters:
        target - Values will be copied to this location.

      • getBucketsFrequency

        public double getBucketsFrequency(int n)
        Get bucket's associated frequency
        Parameters:
        n - Bucket's index
        Returns:
        Bucket's frequency. Returns NaN if invalid index is provided.

      • getClosestFrequency

        public int getClosestFrequency(double f)
        Returns the bucket whose frequency is the closest to f. If one needs do know exactly what is that frequency, use getBucketsFrequency() together with this function.
        Parameters:
        f - The desired frequency
        Returns:
        The bucket. -1 if negative frequency is provided.

      • fastFourierTransform

        protected Signal fastFourierTransform(boolean inverse)
        Naïve implementation of Fast Fourier Transform, i. e., directy implementation of FFT's definition.

      • fft

        public Signal fft()

      • iFFT

        public Signal iFFT()

      • convolve

        public Signal convolve(Signal S)
        Convolves This signal with S. The result is stored in This.
        Parameters:
        S - Our "operand".

      • writeToWAVE

        public void writeToWAVE(java.lang.String filepath,
               SampleSize size)
        Write signal to wave file
        Parameters:
        filepath - File to save
        size - Number of bytes we'll use to sample each point.

      • multiplyElements

        public void multiplyElements(Signal S,
                    int offset)
        Multiply element per element. Works in similar way to Add(), but we multiply the elements instead of add.
        Parameters:
        S - Operand
        offset - Shift signal.

      • multiplyElements

        public void multiplyElements(Signal S)

      • normalize

        public void normalize()
        Keep signal in the range [-1,1]

      • scalarMultiply

        public void scalarMultiply(double scalar)
        Multiply signal by scalar quantity
        Parameters:
        scalar - Scalar quantity

      • add

        public void add(Signal S,
       int offset)
        Signal = Signal + S. Adds a signal to another. This will cause values to go above 1 or under -1! Must normalize after operation
        Parameters:
        S - Operand
        offset - An offset to shift the operand. FOr example, if we have offset = 5, the first 5 positions will not be affected. Note that offset + operand's length must not be greater then Signal length.

      • add

        public void add(Signal S)

      • stdDev

        public double stdDev()
        Get standards deviation of the samples in the signal. Useful for evaluating signal-noise ratio.
        Returns:
        Standard deviation of samples.

      • max

        public double max()
        Returns the sample with greatest ABSOLUTE value.

      • mean

        protected double mean()

      • padWithZeros

        public void padWithZeros(int N)
        Forces This signal to be of length N by adding Zeros in the end.
        Parameters:
        N - Final length of signal

      • clone

        public Signal clone()
        Returns a deep copy of this signal, i.e., no references. This obviously run in O(n), so be careful while cloning stuff
        Overrides:
        clone in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        A signal identical to the one copied but with no references.
